I hope I didn't leave the impression that the neighborhood
associations were the ogres in
this housing situation. Unfortunately, past irresponsible
behavior by fraternities left
neighbors no other choice but
at least to halt any new frat
houses in their areas, if not

Neighbors living near fraternity houses have been abused
repeatedly over the years
through loud and late parties,
post-party trash in their yards,
and shrubbery, plants, and
even car roofs being trampled
by departing guests in various
states of inebriation. All too
often, fraternities took an attitude of indifference or even
"we're fraternities. . we're
allowed to act this way." Not
that individual fraternities
haven't tried at times to be
good neighbors; they have, and
relations between neighbors
and individual fraternities have
for periods of time been quite
good. This harmony only took
place, however, when current
brothers were really willing to
work to make it work.

houses are all off-campus. We

don't have an on-campus frat
row where your only neighbors

houses. Fraternity members
can't isolate themselves in their
houses as might be possible in
campus dorms.. . because

grounds of Homewood...
you're part of neighborhoods
existing in the real world.

houses must make the effort to
genes know and be considerate
of their neighbors if they hope
to survive. Most neighbors are,
in fact, extremely tolerant and
willing to put up with a lot, if
simply granted some mild consideration. Animal House was
only a movie; yet, it seems that
often new members (who apparently have not been properly instructed about neighborhood consideration) find
"Belushi Behavior" to be not
only acceptable behavior for a
member of a fraternity, but
even expected ... when the complete opposite is true.
I don't mean to sound like
the Hopkins version of Miss
Manners, and I do believe that
fraternities can make a positive
contribution to campus life. I
felt that joining a fraternity was
the best thing I could have done
as a student here. There are
others who pledge fraternities
and then soon lose interest in
them and become inactive.
They're not for everyone,
they're certainly not without
imperfections; but for many,
fraternity membership is an im-

portant aspect of a Hopkins
education.

fraternities which I don't
like. ..especially the cruelty

fraternities would not make so
much effort at superficial prejudgement of potential members and instead grant more
committals the opportunity to
prove themselves as individuals
worth getting to know and having as friends.
One progressive aspect of the
major Hopkins social fraternities and sororities(compared
to some schools) is that they are
not organized around any racial
or religious criteria and don't
discriminate on that basis. This
encourages a diversity of
members that you don't often
find in other campus
groups. It is important to
understand as well that (compared to some schook where
the decision to join or not join
a fraternity affects one's social
opportunities for the rest of a
college career) it's really not
that big a deal here (which is
how it should be). Fraternities
and sororities are simply support groups, just like any
athletic team (lacrosse, swimming) or SAC group(BSU, JSA,
the Band, etc.). Dormitory
houses serve the freshmen as
their support group during their
first year here; but once offcampus, these athletic, activity

and fraternal groups play an
important role in Hopkins
students' adjusting to life outside of the dorms. It is also
through these groups that
Hopkins students end up making most of their close
friendships.

Hopkins? First of all, I know
that as a student here, I
wouldn't have been too thrilled about some administrator
from the alumni office telling
me how to run my frat, and
that Las not been my purpose.
My reasons for writing go
beyond what I hope will be
viewed
as constructive
criticism. As a student here, I
felt that I benefited greatly
from my fraternity experience.
It is my hope that others will at
least have the same opportunity that I did to benefit in the
future.
I don't have anything startling to suggest to solve the problems facing fraternities, but a
little common sense and savvy
wouldn't hurt now and then.
Perhaps the IFC should investigate how off-campus
fraternities at other universities
are coping in this new environment. In regards to open parties, a major topic of Chris
Riordan's letter, it seems to me
that fraternities may be missing
the point. It's not the University that has to be convinced of
the desirability and acceptability of open parties, it's the
neighbors. If fraternities

establish good relations with
their neighbors (not just the
week before rush, but all
through the year)and take adequate measures at the time to
control their parties and their
departing guests, then there
shouldn't be any problems.
However, as long as Chris Colombo and Steven Muller get
phone calls from outraged
neighbors at 3:00 a.m., you can
bet that fraternity "problems"
will continue to exist.
It is possible to have fun as
an undergraduate at Hopkins
while getting a good education,
even in this era of restricted access to alcohol. However, if the
notion is not instilled that we
are all responsible for our own
actions, that education is incomplete at best. Hopkins
prides itself on treating the
members of its family as adults,
until proven otherwise.
Hopkins fraternities are no

If you don't already know,
for the second year in a row,
Edward Albee, famous
playwright, author of The Zoo
Story and Who's Afraid of
Virginia Woolf?, and winner of
two Pulitzer prizes, was a
visitor here at Hopkins instructing selected students in the arts
of acting, directing, and
playwrighting. The final products of this instruction—five
student plays—were on view last
weekend to more or less full
houses in the L/V Room.
Unlike last year, however,
Albee didn't direct all the plays
himself; he directed only one of
them—the student directors had
far more control. Nevertheless,
for the second year, the
Hopkins community was
shown that even without a
theatre department, we have
some very talented drama
students going to school here.
The plays were presented as
follows: two on Friday night,
Head Over Heels and The
Physicians(Mrs. Gramophone,
retitled Give the Kid a Break,
wasn't shown as scheduled
because of "problems"); the
other two, Mate in Two and All
in Good Time (Violins,
Violence in the press release)
were shown Saturday night and

again Sunday afternoon; and
the first two plus Give the Kid
a Break were shown Sunday
evening. I saw the Saturday
night and Sunday night editions
and thus was lucky enough to
see all of the plays which were
worked on.
Mate in Two by Andy
Piacsek was the play directed
by Albee and it showed.(AnneMarie Ulrich was his assistant.)
Bruce McKenzie played Owen,
a blue collar worker at "Carpet
King Discount" in the Bronx
and Pamela Koplik played
Janet, a super-wealthy fortyyear old widow. The play
revolves around a weekly chess
game played by the two with a
twist—after each piece captured,
the captor must make a bet,
e.g. if I win you must give me
your panties; and at the end of
the game, the loser must choose
one of the bets at random and
follow through on it. In short,
because of the bets it becomes
a power game—poor vs.
wealthy, female vs. male—this
much is accentuated by Albee
who in making the stage a giant
chess board, populated it with
phallic chess pieces. Furthermore, the bets show the nature
of the struggle—she is always
dressing him like a woman, he
wants her money. The bets
build and thus the tension,
from panties, to burning

pigeons in the park, to picking
lice off a chimp and eating
them, to walking in Central
Park at night until being raped,
and finally to her marrying
him—his grand finale of a bet.
This is coupled with the fact
that she nearly always beats
him, he has the upper hand this
time—the tables are turned and

she's not used to losing—thus
the tension is even stronger.
Finally, with his checkmate of
her, the tension reaches a peak—
will she have to marry him (or
rather, pretend to) but suddenly dissipates as she rips up the
first "questionable" bets she
chooses and chooses "reality"—
to give up her panties. Not on-

ly has Owen gone too far—into
a fantasy world—but the play
seems to be saying that perhaps
in the power games between the
sexes and between the classes
there are things better left under
the surface, unmentioned. The

Jays Bounce Back, Top Garnet
by Mike Silverman
and Adam Warner
After a devastating 82-44 loss
to Widener last Saturday, the
Hopkins basketball team rebounded to break a four game
losing streak in style, trouncing
MAC rival Swarthmore, 89-73,
at the athletic center Wednesday night.
"We came into this game in
a good frame of mind," said
Head Coach Nappy Doherty.
"We got balanced scoring, and
the defense caused a lot of turnovers. I'm hopeful that this
type of play will carry over to
the next Widener game on
Saturday."
The scoring attack against
the Garnet was about as balanced as it could be, as five Jays
hit double figures. The leader
was Charlie Sikorsky, who
came off the bench to pump in
17 points and help the home
team thoroughly dominate the
boards.
The 6'4" junior was closely
followed in the scoring race by
center Ralph Horne, forward
Steve Mitchell, and guard Ken
Puhala, each of whom tallied
14 points. Forward David
Wilson managed 12 points as

well. A sixth Jay, Mike
Kowatch, added seven electrifying points, but he failed to
crack the double digit barrier by
missing three free throws.
As for the game itself, it was
never really much of a contest.
The visitors broke out in front
for an early 12-8 lead, but that
would be their only threat of
the night. Hopkins responded
with a 14 point burst to run the
lead to 22-12. Swarthmore did
not pull within eight points
again, and by halftime the
margin had increased to 13, at
46-33.
Swarthmore made a brief run
out of the gate in the second
half, pulling within ten at 50-40
before the hosts ran off another
streak that would sufficiently
bury them. Hopkins then went
off on a 17-2 run to make the
lead 67-42 with only ten
minutes left.
The big play, perhaps the one
that truly iced the contest, was
turned in by Mike Kowatch.
The 6'2" junior intercepted a
pass on one end of the floor,
dribbled the length of the court
one step ahead of a Garnet
defender, and dunked the ball
home. The crowd rose to applause, and the visitors chose to

burn a timeout. For the remainder of the night, it was
showtime, as the Jays relaxed
with the outcome well in hand.
In the contest against
Widener, the Jays were overcome by a very explosive offense, which had five separate
players score in double figures.
Hopkins was plagued by horrendous shooting (32% from
the field, 47% from the line) as
captain Puhala was the lone
player to achieve double digits,
with 11.
"We played very poorly
overall," said Doherty.
"Widener has won the league
title for the past ten years, and
to beat a team of that caliber,
you have to get good shooting
and strong defensive play. We
weren't able to achieve any of
those objectives against them,
and they just blew us out."
The Blue Jays have the
misfortune of having to travel
to Widener tomorrow (game
time 8:00 p.m.), before returning home to face a Haverford
team next Wednesday. The
season then closes a week from
tomorrow with a road game
against conference power
Washington College.

swimmers includes a weightlifting program and daily practices, but the mental aspect has
to be developed gradually
through the season. To bring
the team closer together and to
take advantage of the Intersession break, Welsh brings his
troops to Palm Beach Florida

the team together," said

The Florida camp features a

and distances in preparation for

Planned attack

To the uninitiated, competitive swimming seems like
nothing more than a constant
effort to go as fast as possible,
but that is not the case. "The
whole season is well planned,
for the team as a whole as well
as for each individual," said
Cutrone. "We know what is
planned for each meet weeks
ahead of time."
"At the beginning of the
season, we look at all of our
people and their previous per-

formances, and then we chart
a set of goals for the coming
year," said Welsh."We have a
lot of meets during a season
each is an opportunity for an
individual swimmer to test
himself. We try to plan ahead
of time where we will be in
terms of progress at each
meet."
This philosophy results in an
individuaiized program for
each swimmer in order to improve his strengths. Johnson,
for example, swims races in
each of the strokes of the
medley relay individually to
prepare him for the combined
event.
This means that the swimmers will gear themselves to
reach their peak at a certain
point during the season,
hopefully enabling them to
make their proverbial "National cuts." The best time during the season varies among the
team members, though the goal
is always to work towards
Nationals.
The "cuts" are time standards that are required for
qualifying to make the trip to
Atlanta, and these are set for
each competitive event. Only
those swimmers who make the
cuts can represent their team,
and, logically, the teams with
the most qualifyers have the
best chance for a high placing.
So far this year, six swimmers have managed to make
their cuts in a total of ten
events. Among them are junior
Wink Dyer in the 100- and
200-yard
breaststroke;
freshman Paul Bowman in the
100- and 200-yard backstroke;
sophomore Dan Fritsch in the
200-yard individual medley;

butterfly; and freshman Mark
Postler in the 200-yard butterfly. In addition, the 400-yard
medley relay team of Bowman,
Segreto, Postler, and Fritsch
has qualified.
Scientific swimming

Training for national qualifying times is an exercise
bordering on science. "The
season generally starts with

light workouts which quickly
become heavy," said Cutrone.
"In the middle there is a little
more chance for rest, but the
yardage stays heavy if the
swimmer can handle it. When
the time comes to make cuts,
the swimmer starts to taper his
workouts in preparation."
"Tapering," which can last
over a month, is a process by
which a swimmer reduces the
intensity of his workouts to
save his energy for the competitive meets. He will start to
rest more and exert himself less
in an effort to prepare himself
mentally and physically.
"Swimmers will taper at different times during the season,
whenever they feel that it is the
right time to go fast," said
Cutrone. "Everyone knows
who is ready to go, who will be
looking to swim fast at each
meet." Usually, the swimmers
will plan to race their best times
against better teams so that the
competition will push them to
go even faster. Many also
"shave down" in order to
reduce drag and to provide a
psychological advantage.
"We've swum our best meets
this year against Princeton,
Yale, and Penn State," said
Welsh, despite the fact that the
Jays as a team lost to all three.
"Against the very good teams
we ignore the scoreboard and
say 'let's take the opportunity
and go fast.' The better competition pushes us to better
times."
Indeed, if titles were decided
by dual meet records, then the
Jays would impress nobody
with their 8-6 mark. Welsh,
however, stresses the importance of strong competition

The Albee Plays: Hopkins Talent on Display
by Peter Oehlkers

If you don't already know,
for the second year in a row,
Edward Albee, famous
playwright, author of The Zoo
Story and Who's Afraid of
Virginia Woolf?, and winner of
two Pulitzer prizes, was a
visitor here at Hopkins instructing selected students in the arts
of acting, directing, and
playwrighting. The final products of this instruction—five
student plays—were on view last
weekend to more or less full
houses in the L/V Room.
Unlike last year, however,
Albee didn't direct all the plays
himself; he directed only one of
them—the student directors had
far more control. Nevertheless,
for the second year, the
Hopkins community was
shown that even without a
theatre department, we have
some very talented drama
students going to school here.
The plays were presented as
follows: two on Friday night,
Head Over Heels and The
Physicians(Mrs. Gramophone,
retitled Give the Kid a Break,
wasn't shown as scheduled
because of "problems"); the
other two, Mate in Two and All
in Good Time (Violins,
Violence in the press release)
were shown Saturday night and

again Sunday afternoon; and
the first two plus Give the Kid
a Break were shown Sunday
evening. I saw the Saturday
night and Sunday night editions
and thus was lucky enough to
see all of the plays which were
worked on.
Mate in Two by Andy
Piacsek was the play directed
by Albee and it showed.(AnneMarie Ulrich was his assistant.)
Bruce McKenzie played Owen,
a blue collar worker at "Carpet
King Discount" in the Bronx
and Pamela Koplik played
Janet, a super-wealthy fortyyear old widow. The play
revolves around a weekly chess
game played by the two with a
twist—after each piece captured,
the captor must make a bet,
e.g. if I win you must give me
your panties; and at the end of
the game, the loser must choose
one of the bets at random and
follow through on it. In short,
because of the bets it becomes
a power game—poor vs.
wealthy, female vs. male—this
much is accentuated by Albee
who in making the stage a giant
chess board, populated it with
phallic chess pieces. Furthermore, the bets show the nature
of the struggle—she is always
dressing him like a woman, he
wants her money. The bets
build and thus the tension,
from panties, to burning

pigeons in the park, to picking
lice off a chimp and eating
them, to walking in Central
Park at night until being raped,
and finally to her marrying
him—his grand finale of a bet.
This is coupled with the fact
that she nearly always beats
him, he has the upper hand this
time—the tables are turned and

she's not used to losing—thus
the tension is even stronger.
Finally, with his checkmate of
her, the tension reaches a peak—
will she have to marry him (or
rather, pretend to) but suddenly dissipates as she rips up the
first "questionable" bets she
chooses and chooses "reality"—
to give up her panties. Not on-

ly has Owen gone too far—into
a fantasy world—but the play
seems to be saying that perhaps
in the power games between the
sexes and between the classes
there are things better left under
the surface, unmentioned. The

Bigelow as Mr. Derrienne and

but all the acting is better than
you would expect from the people sitting next to you in class.
This is an excellent play to try
out Hopkins' Merrick Barn. It
plays well to a small audience,
and it isn't too avant, providing
a really fun substitute to the
usual weekend movie routine.
The atmosphere is great; the
Barn may well be the most interesting building on campus.
The set is rather crude, but it
doesn't figure into the play very

much. It is the actors who carry
the viewer into a strange little
English inn, complete with welldone accents. The stage is used
efficiently, showing very solid
directing by Mr. DeBoy. The
lighting and technical aspects
are adequate, even if one is beat
over the head with the "Three
Blind Mice" a little much. One
of the nice things about the
Merrick Barn that comes
through even better in more artistic plays is the feeling of the
production "going on all
around." The theater-goer is
close enough to hear feet shuffle and lights crackle without
being distracted by this "you
are there" aspect.

The play solves itself, but it's
doubtful you will be able to
guess the ending. Agatha
Christie always saves a turn for
the last. There is a good murder
scene for those in need of a
graphic violence fix, and the
person who gets murdered is
just the one who probably
deserves it. If there are any major problems, they probably lie
in the speed of the delivery. The
actors perform at Shakespearean speed, but one would
rather have them slow down a
bit. The English are not a hurried people. "The Mousetrap"
plays February 7-10, and tickets
and information are available
at the Union Desk, 338-8197.

the next Widener game on
Saturday."

the Garnet was about as balanced as it could be, as five Jays

was Charlie Sikorsky, who
came off the bench to pump in
17 points and help the home
team thoroughly dominate the
boards.
The 6'4" junior was closely
followed in the scoring race by
center Ralph Horne, forward
Steve Mitchell, and guard Ken
Puhala, each of whom tallied
14 points. Forward David
Wilson managed 12 points as

Kowatch, added seven electrifying points, but he failed to

missing three free throws.

for an early 12-8 lead, but that
would be their only threat of
the night. Hopkins responded

lead to 22-12. Swarthmore did
not pull within eight points
again, and by halftime the
margin had increased to 13, at
46-33.

out of the gate in the second
half, pulling within ten at 50-40

streak that would sufficiently
bury them. Hopkins then went
off on a 17-2 run to make the
lead 67-42 with only ten
minutes left.

that truly iced the contest, was
turned in by Mike Kowatch.

pass on one end of the floor,
dribbled the length of the court
one step ahead of a Garnet
defender, and dunked the ball
home. The crowd rose to applause, and the visitors chose to

with the outcome well in hand.

captain Puhala was the lone
player to achieve double digits,
with 11.

overall," said Doherty.
"Widener has won the league
title for the past ten years, and
to beat a team of that caliber,
you have to get good shooting
and strong defensive play. We
weren't able to achieve any of
those objectives against them,
and they just blew us out."

misfortune of having to travel
to Widener tomorrow (game
time 8:00 p.m.), before returning home to face a Haverford
team next Wednesday. The
season then closes a week from
tomorrow with a road game
against conference power
Washington College.

Planned attack

To the uninitiated, competitive swimming seems like
nothing more than a constant
effort to go as fast as possible,
but that is not the case. "The
whole season is well planned,
for the team as a whole as well
as for each individual," said
Cutrone. "We know what is
planned for each meet weeks
ahead of time."

season, we look at all of our
people and their previous per-

formances, and then we chart
a set of goals for the coming
year," said Welsh."We have a
lot of meets during a season
each is an opportunity for an
individual swimmer to test
himself. We try to plan ahead
of time where we will be in
terms of progress at each
meet."
This philosophy results in an
individuaiized program for
each swimmer in order to improve his strengths. Johnson,
for example, swims races in

medley relay individually to
prepare him for the combined
event.

hopefully enabling them to

qualifying to make the trip to

those swimmers who make the
cuts can represent their team,
and, logically, the teams with
the most qualifyers have the
best chance for a high placing.

yardage stays heavy if the
swimmer can handle it. When
the time comes to make cuts,
the swimmer starts to taper his
workouts in preparation."
"Tapering," which can last
over a month, is a process by
which a swimmer reduces the
intensity of his workouts to
save his energy for the competitive meets. He will start to
rest more and exert himself less
in an effort to prepare himself
mentally and physically.
"Swimmers will taper at different times during the season,

right time to go fast," said
Cutrone. "Everyone knows
who is ready to go, who will be
